tasks.title: Principle: Supply & Demand
tasks.description: Watch a 15-min video on the fundamentals of Supply and Demand. This is the master principle.

tasks.title: Find S/D 'Spark'
tasks.description: Find one news headline where an asset (stock/crypto) moved > 5%. Ask: 'What did this news do to the *supply*? What did it do to the *demand*?'

tasks.title: 1-Paragraph Analyst Note
tasks.description: Write one paragraph: 'Today, [Asset] moved [X%]. The news was [Spark]. This likely happened because it [increased/decreased] [supply/demand] by [explain reason].'

tasks.title: 60-Second S/D Memo
tasks.description: Record a 1-min voice note explaining your written paragraph, as if to a friend. Use simple words like 'want' (demand) and 'available' (supply).

tasks.title: Principle: Incentives
tasks.description: Read a short article on 'economic incentives'. Understand that all market participants (buyers, sellers, companies) act based on incentives.

tasks.title: Find 'Incentive' Spark
tasks.description: Find a headline about a company's decision (e.g., 'Tesla cuts prices,' 'Apple announces buyback'). Ask: 'What is the *incentive* for them to do this? How does this *incentivize* customers/investors?'

tasks.title: Incentive List
tasks.description: In your journal, create two lists for your 'Spark': 1) 'Incentives for the company to do this:' 2) 'Incentives for customers/investors to react:'

tasks.title: Explain the 'Why'
tasks.description: Record a 1-min voice note. Don't state the news. Just explain the *incentives* behind it. 'Here's why [Company] did [X]... They are incentivized by...'

tasks.title: Assets: Stock vs. Crypto
tasks.description: Watch one 10-min video explaining 'What is a stock?' and another 10-min video on 'What is cryptocurrency? (e.g., Bitcoin)'. Focus on what gives them *value*.

tasks.title: Compare S/D
tasks.description: Think about Bitcoin vs. Apple stock. How is the *supply* of each determined? What factors drive *demand* for each? Are they different?

tasks.title: Venn Diagram / T-Chart
tasks.description: In your journal, draw a T-chart or Venn diagram comparing the Supply/Demand factors for Bitcoin vs. a stock like Apple. Write 2-3 points for each.

tasks.title: Explain the Difference
tasks.description: Record a 2-min memo explaining the *key* difference in what drives value for a stock versus a cryptocurrency, based on your T-chart.

tasks.title: Mechanics: Order Books
tasks.description: Watch a 15-min video on 'how an exchange order book works'. Understand 'bid', 'ask', and 'market orders'. This is the *engine* of S/D.

tasks.title: Find a 'Volume' Spark
tasks.description: Find a headline that mentions 'high trading volume'. Ask: 'What does high volume mean in the context of an order book? Does it mean lots of buyers, sellers, or both?'

tasks.title: Predictive Journal Entry
tasks.description: Find a *new* Spark. Before checking the price chart, write a prediction: 'The news is [Spark]. I believe this will [increase/decrease] [demand/supply]. Therefore, the price should [go up/down].'

tasks.title: Speak Your Prediction
tasks.description: Record a 1-min memo *before* you check the price. State your prediction and your 'why' clearly. Save it.

tasks.title: Review Prediction
tasks.description: Listen to yesterday's memo. Now look at the chart. Were you right or wrong? *Why?* What did you miss? This feedback loop is critical.

tasks.title: Prediction Review
tasks.description: In your journal, under yesterday's entry, write a 'Review:' paragraph. 'My prediction was [correct/wrong]. I was right/wrong because... The key factor I missed was...'

tasks.title: Explain Your Mistake (or Win)
tasks.description: Record a 2-min memo. The topic is 'What I learned from my last prediction.' Be honest and analytical about your thought process.

tasks.title: Passive Review
tasks.description: Just browse financial news for 10 minutes. See if you can spot the S/D and incentive language in the articles.

tasks.title: S/D Deep Dive: 'Elasticity'
tasks.description: Watch a 10-min video on 'price elasticity of demand'. Ask: 'Is the demand for Bitcoin 'elastic' or 'inelastic'? What about gasoline?'

tasks.title: Find 'Elasticity' Spark
tasks.description: Find news about a price *change* for a common good (like gas, coffee, or a new phone). Ask: 'Will this price change cause a *big* drop in demand (elastic) or a *small* one (inelastic)? Why?'

tasks.title: Elastic/Inelastic Note
tasks.description: Write a short note: '[Product] prices are changing. I think the demand is [elastic/inelastic] because... This means the company's total revenue will likely [go up/go down].'

tasks.title: Explain Elasticity
tasks.description: Record a 1-min memo explaining your 'elastic' or 'inelastic' call as if to a fellow analyst.

tasks.title: Weekly Review
tasks.description: Read through your entire journal for Week 1. What was the most surprising connection you found? What are you still most confused about?

tasks.title: Week 1 Summary
tasks.description: Write a 3-bullet-point summary: 'My 3 Key Takeaways on Supply & Demand'. 2. 'My Biggest Question Remaining.'

tasks.title: Weekly Summary Memo
tasks.description: Record a 3-minute memo summarizing your 3 takeaways and your biggest question. This solidifies the week's learning.

tasks.title: Macro Principle: 'The Price of Money'
tasks.description: Learn: **Interest Rates** (cost of borrowing), **Central Banks** (e.g., US Fed, RBI - they set the rates), **Inflation** (prices rising). Watch a 20-min explainer on how these 3 interact.

tasks.title: Find Macro 'Spark'
tasks.description: Find the *latest* news on an interest rate decision or inflation report (CPI) from the US or India.

tasks.title: Start the 'Chain of Logic'
tasks.description: In your journal, start the chain: '1. News: [e.g., Inflation is high]. 2. This means Central Bank will [raise rates]. 3. Why? [To slow spending]. 4. So what...'

tasks.title: Practice the Chain
tasks.description: Record a 1-min memo trying to speak out your 'Chain of Logic' so far. This will reveal gaps in your understanding.

tasks.title: Macro Principle: GDP
tasks.description: Watch a 10-min video on 'What is GDP (Gross Domestic Product)?'. Understand what it means when it's 'growing' or 'shrinking'.

tasks.title: Find GDP 'Spark'
tasks.description: Find your country's (or the US's) latest GDP report. Was it higher or lower than expected? What does that imply about the economy's health?

tasks.title: GDP 'So What?' Note
tasks.description: Write a paragraph: 'The latest GDP report showed [growth/shrinkage]. This was [above/below] expectations. This suggests the economy is [hot/cold], which means the Central Bank might be [more/less] likely to [raise/lower] rates.'

tasks.title: Explain GDP News
tasks.description: Record a 1-min memo explaining why the 'boring' GDP number matters, connecting it to the Central Bank and interest rates.

tasks.title: Connect Week 1 & 2
tasks.description: The key connection: How do *interest rates* (Week 2) affect the *demand* for assets (Week 1)? Hint: If a 'safe' bank account pays 5%, are you as 'demanding' of a risky stock?

tasks.title: The 'Gravity' Note
tasks.description: Write a paragraph explaining this connection. Title it 'Interest Rates are Gravity.' (e.g., 'Higher rates pull money *out* of risky assets... this *decreases demand* for stocks/crypto, so prices fall.')

tasks.title: Explain 'Gravity'
tasks.description: Record a 2-min memo explaining the 'Rates as Gravity' analogy to a friend. This is a core concept.

tasks.title: Find New Macro Spark
tasks.description: Find any new macro (inflation, rates, GDP) headline. This time, *predict* the market reaction for both stocks and crypto.

tasks.title: Macro Prediction Journal
tasks.description: Write a new prediction entry: 'Event: [Macro Spark]. My Chain: [e.g., News -> Rates -> Demand]. Prediction (Stocks): [Down]. Prediction (Crypto): [Down].'

tasks.title: The 'Dinner Table' Pitch
tasks.description: Record a 2-min memo explaining your prediction. Goal: Make it a clear, compelling story. 'Here's what just happened, and here's why it means [X]...'

tasks.title: Review Prediction
tasks.description: Check yesterday's prediction against the market. Were you right/wrong? *Why?* Did the market do the opposite? (This happens! Why?)

tasks.title: Prediction Review
tasks.description: Write your review: 'My prediction was [correct/wrong]. The market [did/didn't] do what I expected. I think this is because [e.g., the news was already 'priced in', or I missed...].'

tasks.title: Explain 'Priced In'
tasks.description: Record a 1-min memo on the concept of news being 'priced in' (i.e., the market already expected it, so there was no reaction).

tasks.title: Podcast: 'Planet Money'
tasks.description: Listen to one 20-30 minute episode of 'Planet Money' or 'The Indicator' podcast related to a macro topic. This is active, on-the-go learning.

tasks.title: Podcast Summary
tasks.description: Write 3 bullet points summarizing the podcast episode. 1) What was the main topic? 2) What was the key insight? 3) What is one new question you have?

tasks.title: Podcast Insight
tasks.description: Record a 1-min memo on the 'key insight' you just wrote down.

tasks.title: Weekly Review
tasks.description: Read your Week 2 journal. What is the *clearest* connection between Macro (rates) and Markets (S/D)? What is the *muddiest*?

tasks.title: Week 2 Summary
tasks.description: Write 3 bullet points: 'My 3 Key Takeaways on Macroeconomics'. 2. 'My Biggest Question Remaining.'

tasks.title: Weekly Summary Memo
tasks.description: Record a 3-minute memo summarizing your 3 takeaways and your biggest question. This solidifies the week's learning.

tasks.title: Psychology: 'Risk-On/Risk-Off'
tasks.description: Learn this concept. **Risk-On:** Investors feel 'greedy' (buy stocks/crypto). **Risk-Off:** Investors feel 'fearful' (sell risk, buy 'safe' bonds/cash). Watch a 15-min video.

tasks.title: Connect Macro & Psychology
tasks.description: How does macro news *cause* a 'Risk-Off' mood? (e.g., 'Bad inflation report -> Fed raises rates -> Fear of recession -> Risk-Off!'). Trace this.

tasks.title: Find the 'Mood'
tasks.description: Look at the market today (e.g., S&P 500 or Bitcoin). Is it a 'Risk-On' or 'Risk-Off' day? Find one headline and write: 'The market feels [Risk-On/Off]. I think this is driven by [News Spark].'

tasks.title: Explain the 'Mood'
tasks.description: Record a 1-min memo: 'Today, the market sentiment is [mood], and the main driver seems to be...'

tasks.title: Psychology: 'FOMO & FUD'
tasks.description: Learn 'Fear Of Missing Out' (FOMO) and 'Fear, Uncertainty, Doubt' (FUD). These drive bubbles and crashes.

tasks.title: Find 'Emotion' Spark
tasks.description: Find a headline about a meme stock or a crypto coin making a *nonsensical* 50%+ move. Ask: 'Is this FOMO or FUD?'

tasks.title: The 'Contrarian' Note
tasks.description: Write a paragraph arguing *against* the crowd. 'Everyone is buying [Meme Coin] due to FOMO. This is irrational because [list 1-2 fundamental reasons]. This is likely a bubble.'

tasks.title: The 'Contrarian' Argument
tasks.description: Record a 2-min memo making your contrarian case. This practices independent thinking.

tasks.title: Valuation: 'P/E Ratio'
tasks.description: Learn what the 'Price-to-Earnings (P/E)' Ratio is. It's a *basic* (not perfect) check for 'cheap' vs. 'expensive'.

tasks.title: Apply P/E
tasks.description: Look up the P/E ratio for two competitors (e.g., Google vs. Microsoft, or Ford vs. Tesla). Which is 'cheaper'? Why might the 'expensive' one have a high P/E?

tasks.title: P/E Comparison
tasks.description: Write a short note: '[Company A] has a P/E of [X] and [Company B] has a P/E of [Y]. [Company B] is 'more expensive' because the market *expects* it to grow faster. This is [psychology/fundamentals].'

tasks.title: Explain P/E
tasks.description: Record a 1-min memo explaining which company is 'cheaper' and *why* the other is more expensive.

tasks.title: Find 'Fundamentals vs. Psych'
tasks.description: Find news about a stock (e.g., NVIDIA, Tesla). Ask: 'Is this news impacting its *fundamentals* (long-term profit) or just its *psychology* (short-term FOMO)?'

tasks.title: Fundamentals vs. Psych Journal
tasks.description: Write a prediction: 'The news is [Spark]. I think this is 90% psychology / 10% fundamentals. Therefore, the price move [will/will not] last.'

tasks.title: Argue Your Case
tasks.description: Record a 2-min memo arguing your 'psychology vs. fundamentals' call. Justify your percentage breakdown.

tasks.title: The 'Safe' Asset: Bonds
tasks.description: Watch a 15-min video on 'What is a government bond?' and 'What is a 'yield'?'. This is the benchmark for 'Risk-Off'.

tasks.title: The 'Yield' Connection
tasks.description: Key concept: 'Why buy risky Bitcoin (0% yield) if a 'safe' government bond yields 5%?' How does the bond yield affect *demand* for crypto?

tasks.title: Bonds vs. Crypto Note
tasks.description: Write a paragraph explaining the competition: 'As bond yields [rise], they become [more] attractive. This pulls money *away* from non-yielding assets like crypto and gold, [decreasing] their demand.'

tasks.title: Explain the Competition
tasks.description: Record a 1-min memo. Start with: 'If I offered you a 5% safe return, would you still gamble...'

tasks.title: Prediction Review
tasks.description: Review all your predictions from Weeks 1-3. Where are you consistently wrong? Are you too optimistic (FOMO)? Too pessimistic (FUD)?

tasks.title: Identify Your 'Bias'
tasks.description: Write a paragraph: 'My biggest bias so far seems to be... I tend to [overestimate/underestimate] the impact of [e.g., psychology, rates].'

tasks.title: Confess Your Bias
tasks.description: Record a 2-min memo acknowledging your bias and stating one way you'll try to correct for it next week.

tasks.title: Weekly Review
tasks.description: Read your Week 3 journal. How does 'emotion' interact with the 'logic' of Week 1 and 2? Which one seems to win more often in the short term?

tasks.title: Week 3 Summary
tasks.description: Write 3 bullet points: 'My 3 Key Takeaways on Market Psychology'. 2. 'My Biggest Question Remaining.'

tasks.title: Weekly Summary Memo
tasks.description: Record a 3-minute memo summarizing your 3 takeaways and your biggest question. This solidifies the week's learning.

tasks.title: Synthesis: Geopolitics & Oil
tasks.description: Learn how **Oil** is the 'master commodity' (it's an input cost for everything). Learn how **Geopolitics** (conflicts, alliances) affects oil *supply*.

tasks.title: Find 'Geopolitical' Spark
tasks.description: Find a headline about OPEC, a conflict in the Middle East, or oil prices.

tasks.title: Start the 'Full Chain' Map
tasks.description: In your journal, trace the *entire chain*. '1. Event: [OPEC cuts supply]. 2. Impact: Oil *supply* down (Wk 1). 3. Consequence: Gas prices *up*. 4. Macro: This is *inflation* (Wk 2). 5. CB Reaction: ...'

tasks.title: Complete the 'Full Chain'
tasks.description: Finish yesterday's chain map. Connect it all the way to Week 3. '...CB raises rates -> Fear of recession -> 'Risk-Off' mood (Wk 3) -> People sell stocks/crypto.'

tasks.title: Write the 'Full Chain' Story
tasks.description: Turn your chain map into a 2-paragraph story. 'It started with an OPEC decision, but it ended with the crypto market falling. Here's how...'

tasks.title: Speak the 'Full Chain'
tasks.description: Record a 2-min memo telling this story. This is the ultimate synthesis test.

tasks.title: Synthesis: Regulation & Tariffs
tasks.description: Learn how new *laws*, *regulations*, or *tariffs* (taxes on imports) act as new *incentives* (Wk 1) for companies.

tasks.title: Find 'Political' Spark
tasks.description: Find a headline about a new law, a politician threatening regulation (e.g., on AI or crypto), or new tariffs.

tasks.title: Trace the 'Incentive' Chain
tasks.description: Write a chain: '1. Event: [New tariff on solar panels]. 2. Incentive: [More expensive to import]. 3. Company Action: [Buy domestic, or raise prices]. 4. Market Impact: [Domestic solar stocks *up*, other prices *up*].'

tasks.title: Explain the Political Impact
tasks.description: Record a 2-min memo explaining how this *political* decision will *economically* affect companies and consumers.

tasks.title: Find Your 'Capstone' Spark
tasks.description: Find the *biggest* financial/political news story of the day. It doesn't matter what it is.

tasks.title: The 'Capstone' Memo
tasks.description: Write a 300-word memo titled 'Why [Spark] Matters.' Use *all* your principles: S/D (Wk 1), Macro (Wk 2), Psychology (Wk 3), and Political links (Wk 4). This is your 'final exam' for writing.

tasks.title: Memo Read-Through
tasks.description: Read your Capstone Memo out loud to yourself. This helps catch awkward phrasing and flawed logic. Make edits.

tasks.title: Refine the 'Capstone'
tasks.description: Re-read yesterday's memo. Find the *single most important sentence* (the 'thesis'). Your speaking task will be built around this.

tasks.title: The 60-Second 'CEO Briefing'
tasks.description: This is your 'final exam' for speaking. Record a 60-second, high-energy brief of your memo. Format: 1. 'Here's what happened.' 2. 'Here's why it matters.' 3. 'Here's what I'm watching next.' Do it 5-10 times until it's *perfect*.

tasks.title: Full Journal Review
tasks.description: Read your entire 4-week journal, from Day 1. Look at your first 'Spark' vs. your 'Capstone' memo. How has your thinking changed?

tasks.title: My 'Gaps & Gains' List
tasks.description: Write two lists: 1. 'My 3 Biggest Gains' (e.g., 'I now understand rates'). 2. 'My 3 Biggest Gaps' (e.g., 'I still don't get bonds', 'My bias is...').

tasks.title: Course Summary Memo
tasks.description: Record a 3-min memo summarizing your 'Gaps & Gains'.

tasks.title: My Ongoing 'Analyst's Loop'
tasks.description: The course is over; the habit begins. Write a 1-page document defining your new sustainable routine. 'I will analyze [X] Sparks per week.' 'I will journal [X] times.' 'I will review my predictions every [Sunday].'

tasks.title: My 'Mission Statement'
tasks.description: Record a 3-minute 'mission statement' for your continued learning. 'My goal is to... I will achieve this by focusing on... I will avoid...'

tasks.title: Find Your Sources
tasks.description: Final task: Find 3-5 high-quality analysts, podcasts, or newsletters to follow. Your learning is now about *curation* and *application*.
